text:
I can't believe how this place has expanded! I was put off by FOUR hosts when we first walked up... told it would be a 2 hour wait and they weren't welcoming AT ALL. We were going to grab a drink and go somewhere else, but the waitress in the bar said she would serve us in there (Elizabeth) and she totally turned our experience around. 

Food is tasty. Don't have high expectations for portion size. I ordered the Pan Seared Escolar, which was wonderful It was served with snap peas and crispy potatoes. OK, so the potatoes looked like a Parmesan crisp served on top of the fish, not a side dish at all. There were 3 (THREE!!!) snap peas. Someone ordered the flash fried lobster, that was good. Someone else ordered the fillet - he said it was good. They still have the sticky buns...yum! White Cosmo was super great, best martini ever. 

Pricey and a little overstated for my taste, but still a good experience all around. BTW... walked the restaurant after dinner, tons of empty tables. Don't understand the 2 hour wait???? Make a reservation... Thanks Elizabeth!

Went here for a belated mothers day celebration. Loved it! Had two delicious signature cocktails, a lemon drop martini and a spiced rum old fashioned. Had the mussels to start, a mozzarella salad and then the pork tenderloin. It was all so good, I will absolutely come back again.  My server John was amazing with his wine knowledge. I wish I had had enough room for dessert but there's always next time!

Service was a little slow, but the food was really good. The scalloped potatoes that came with the filet were awesome. Plus the sticky buns were really good.  The view of Camelback Mountain from out table was pretty awesome also.

We at at El Chorro this morning and we were VERY DISAPPOINTED ... 
The food was flavorless and overpriced.
I ordered a sandwich with a side of mayonnaise and it must have been from the night before. it had congealed and there was ketchup on the bottom of the bowl (like it had been taken off someones plate and reused) ... It was nasty and did not spread. Once we complained to the waitress we were comped my sandwich but no other apologies made...
We spent over $90.00 for 2 adults and 3 children for a Sunday morning brunch (which included 1 mimosa.) Wow... $4 Orange Juices and $10.00 chicken tenders.
Don't waste your money unless you are just trying to find a restaurant with a good view.

On  Saturday, April 25th, my wife and I had dinner at El Chorro.  We had the Chateaubriand for two.  It was excellent, and the service was as well, other than it took a very long time to get our food.  This was due to the fact that, unfortunately, the power in the kitchen went out during our dinner.  On top of the delay in receiving our meal, we did not get dessert.  While many patrons that night were not charged for their meals, we paid for ours in full and left a generous tip.  We were told at the reception desk upon leaving that El Chorro would contact us about dessert.  No one did.  Finally my wife called the restaurant on October 1st and spoke with the general manager, Ryan.  He needs professional development in customer service.  He displayed an uncaring attitude about the fact our experience at dinner on April 25th was less than perfect.  He even told my wife that he didn't know what she expected him to do about the fact we did not get dessert, since the power outage was out of El Chorro's control.  Finally Ryan relented and said he would send us a gift card for our dessert.  It arrived - $10.  Really?  Each dessert probably costs $10.  So he sent us a gift card for one dessert.  The better approach would have been to actually care that a customer had a less than satisfactory experience, or at least act like you cared.  Maybe even discount the dinner we already paid for, or offer a free return dining experience at El Chorro.  But no, Ryan had attitude during the entire conversation and then sent us one (1) $10 gift card.  That's how he took care of the fact we got no dessert after paying over $200 for dinner.  Again, sign up for the next seminar on customer service that you can, Ryan.

Great service, atmosphere, and food. Good wine selection too. I like the outdoor seating with all the fireplaces. Great for a date or large party. I had the salmon for dinner and it was cooked to perfection. Don't leave without having a sticky bun.

They get the most stars for the patio seating and sticky buns. My complaints are that the latte I got tasted like really bad espresso and was room temperature. The food was okay but not worth the price. Also, we had the bussers come by three times in a row and try to take our plates when we weren't finished, which felt like they were trying to rush us out of there and pretty rude. I wouldn't go out of my way to go back.

I really enjoy this place.  The atmosphere is the best, the food is great and the staff is wonderful.  Thanks to Phillip last night who was a wonderful server.  Only had bad service once.  They keep the patio temperature great no matter what time of years.  Great for special occasions.

As a professional event planner, I am VERY picky about where I do my events. Hands down, El Charro is my favorite restaurant for private group dinners and intimate special events. The food and service are exceptional, the ambiance is vintage-Arizona, the prices are appropriate, the patio is one of the best in East Valley, the location is convenient, and the owners are very friendly and engaging. The special events staff is very prompt and responsive. It is a real pleasure doing business with El Charro.
Beautiful ambiance...brunch was delicious...service terrific!

I always love gong to a local staple and if you are looking for a culinary classic search no further. The best dishes are the deep fried lobster wit the drawn butter and the sticky rolls are to die for.

El Chorro is one of the best patio dining experiences in the Valley during the "good weather" months.  The food is good and the ambiance great.  That pretty much sums it up for me.  The service is usually very good.  If you are looking for great outdoor ambiance on a perfect Arizona evening then this is the place.  Plus, where else can you chat up Alice Cooper while waiting in line for the hostess?

I had an amazing birthday dinner here. I am still craving the sticky buns which they bring you before your meal. The food was amazing the service was also excellent. I will definitely be back for another special occasion! The food took a while to come out but our server was apologetic.

The place has such potential as it is a beautiful location.  The building is clean and seems to be newly renovated, the landscaping is perfect for the desert.  That unfortunately is where the great feeling for El Charro ends.  

The bartender was short tempered and didn't seem to like people or her job.  We all seemed like an inconvenience.  She preferred to huddle with the other servers and chat rather than serve drinks.  

The food was mediocre.  I had the burrata and tomato salad.  It is prime tomato season and they were flavorless and underripe.  I was surprised they were served.  The truffle fries were something I would expect to see from a Chili's or TGI Friday's; covered in grated cheese.  The rest of the meal followed suit.  The plates were expensive for the quality which was lacking.    

The front desk staff was friendly.  The flowers on the patio were nice and the local art on the walls was fun.   These few things will not compel me to return.

Had dinner there on Black Friday. Past experience was not good. This time the food for our party of 4 was excellent. Hostess was gracious and polite, our waiter was on the ball asking all the right question . Food was amazing, great presentation, taste and service. El Chorro is back on my radar as a fine Scottsdale and PV favorite.

I love the view, food and service here. I love dinner and brunch at El Chorro. I just adore everything about this restaurant. (No, the sticky buns are not a draw for me :) I personally think they are weird with wine and dinner-I guess I am not a sticky buns kind of girl) Love the patio!This is one of my favorite places in the valley.

Expensive, relaxed, sultry, with a ginormous motherload sized patio and courtyard area - quintessentially Phoenix (or should I say PV). 

My first time here ever so cannot compare to the old and on a Wednesday didn't have a reservation so was seated in the bar patio with the bar menu. The cheese & charcuterie platter was fabulous but the steak & onion soup was the rogue menu addition and bad order choice (great steak but processed onion flavor).  ***Warning*** $15 Chopin martinis...but it was fabulous and so was the view. I could really learn to love $15 martinis here.... of course I can also imagine the valet bringing me back a Bugatti when I leave. 

Eager to return for a main course or happy hour again...
Thank you for showing me How Great El Chorro can be! It's Great to know when management really cares about their company. I truly appreciate the contact.

This was recommend as a must do for fine dining. The views and atmosphere were breathtaking. Warm mini cinnamon buns in lieu of bread basket, OMG! Server was attentive. My steak was good. I was a wonderful date night out. Will do again!

Update...went back again with old friends. Beautiful surroundings...and that's it. Rude service once again. I'm done with this place. Makes me so sad, so many happy memories here. Customer service is everything and they just don't have it here.

Very, very disappointed in their Happy Hour.  For such an expensive and well known restaurant, the liquor and wine served during their Happy Hour is the cheapest I've ever seen in a restaurant bar.  The wine was so awful it was undrinkable.  The vodka served was Smirnoff -- how cheap is that!  Management should be embarrassed.  Charge a little more and give patrons your regular liquor and wine at a discount.  Don't say you offer a Happy Hour and then serve the lowest quality liquor and wine available when you should call it "Cheap Liquor and Wine Hour"! There are many very good bars around the city that care about having their patrons return and who offer a LIGITIMATE Happy Hour. The management should take a lesson from Dominicks and The Village Tavern. They know how to offer a REAL Happy Hour and they don't insult their patrons.

Stopped in with a group for brunch. What's not to love? There is such ambiance at EC. It's warm and inviting. The food was wonderful, and our server was an absolute doll. Thank you so much for a wonderful meal!
For some reason, the sticky buns were awful, dry and so hard and chewy they were difficult to cut with a knife. Disappointing since the sticky buns are the draw for me.

Outstanding again!  Took an out of town guest there for dinner, the food was outstanding!  I had the salmon and my friend had the jumbo shrimp, both were spectacular!  Beautiful setting on the north side of Camelback Mountain!  I'll be going back!
I love this place!!! Great food, awesome ambiance, terrific service, extensive wine list and nice happy hour!!! Its got so much history too!!! My fave hangout!!!

Service was great they got us a table outside. Vicki our server was great. Has the sausage and the shrimp appetizers very nice. My son and I both had the ahi Tuna - his was perfect mine was cooked perfectly but was cold as was the rice so I sent it back - then a rude person ( manager?) brought out my new one and it was way over cooked - probably took mine back and put it in the microwave- she indicated "heres your hot ahi and were not going to charge you" hey charge me just bring what I ordered ...anyway I didn't want to send it back again as the others at my table were almost done...
My wife's Trout was superb.
I would try it again but when I'm dropping $500 for dinner for 5 with wine I expect good service and good food - don't do me any favors by not charging me for first cold then way overlooked ahi..
Everyone but the person who brought my second plate out was nice - she should stay in back.

Great breakfast / brunch spot.  The setting, service and food are top notch. Prices may be $1-3 more  per entree than other breakfast spots but well worth it.  The sticky buns are unmatched.  Menu has plenty of solid choices and both adults' and childrens' meals were tasty (and our kids are tough judges).  The service is pleasant, prompt and classy (Houston's caliber.)  Another important breakfast barometer, coffee quality.  Again, A+.   Decor is old school AZ in a high-end though unpretentious way.  Parking is ample with optional valet.  We'll be back here soon and often.

Sticky buns...I repeat...ooey gooey sticky buns, with a soft dough interior and cinnamon running throughout, they are divine (and to top it off free!).  Greeting you at breakfast, lunch, or dinner, is a basket of these infamous sticky buns.  

After filling up on these buns, we had the omelette of the day (ham and cheese with assorted grilled veggies) and the canadian bacon eggs benedict.
- Omelette 3.5/5: fluffy, light eggs with lots of cheese but little on the fillings. Cost- $16
- Eggs benedict 4/5: egg perfectly cooked and still runny, sauce was light and flavorful.  Cost- $18

Weekend Brunch menu has small plates, salads, sandwiches/burgers, and about 8-9 breakfast options.  

The restaurant setting is breath-taking.  Outdoor patio with lamp heaters and fireplaces, wraps for women who are cold, and Echo Mountain as the backdrop...could you ask for anything more?!

Summary: Would I bring friends here: YES.  Would I come back: YES for special occasions but not on a weekly basis because of the price.

Have been here twice now and both times have been a magical experience. Food was excellent, and the beautiful setting whether you sit inside or out is enjoyable. The staff was informative and helpful, and they discreetly take care of things. Some restaurants of this caliber have too many folks hovering if you know what I mean. Great experience all the way around and I highly recomme

One star for the decor. It was empty and that should have been a clue. But, I insisted on my boyfriend taking me. We sat on the patio  just outside the 00 bar area. It was beautiful! But the happy hour food was 0! The fried deviled eggs- nasty! The perfect storm was a nasy storm full of fried shrimp and bottom grade calamari. The sliders wher okay but don't compare to Delux Burger. Unhappy, greased out we spent $60 and now  headed to Tarbel's!

El Chorro is a family favorite. The first time I went for my 19th birthday they had their band sing me happy birthday along with the rest of the restaurant. It was a memorable experience and since then I frequent at least once every few months! Service is great, food is great and they have an excellent happy hour!

After finding the desk filled with six women with headsets who looked and acted like they were directing a moon landing we were seated outside next to two tables of tourists wearing t shirts and cargo pants.  Menus were left and perused.  The dishes were very outdated and expensive.  Nothing looked inviting unless you were a 70 year old from Peoria or someone who doesn't dine out more than once a year.  After fifteen minutes of being ignored we left and escaped with our dignity and stomach lining intact.  Go to Arcadia!

Your response simply confirms my original complaint that El Chorro does not accommodate diners with food allergies (re-read how you totally ignored my complaint).  At El Chorro, diners must apparently accommodate your chef not themselves.   I appreciate that you serve 400 people at once but you should do it one customer at a tine.  And when we were there, the dining room was only half full.  Apparently you disregarded my complaint with an odd offer to have us back.  We left Sunday because there was no one item on the menu that my daughter could have.  Not one thing. And you wouldn't even leave out cheese (which she is allergic to) from an omelette so she could find something to eat.   Because of your unnecessary inflexibility, anyone with or without a food allergy that would like to be in control of what they eat  should avoid El Charro.  It could be toxic.

I went to El Chorro's around 6 pm with my wife and a friend from Chicago this past Saturday and will never go back there again. The host claimed that there were no tables available and that we would have to sit at the bar. We counted more than twenty open tables when we arrived and the same number when we left approximately 1.5 hours later. The food and drinks were ok and our waitperson was good, but overall, a very unpleasant experience.

worst brunch on 10/31 i have ever had. ordered eggs benedict with salmon for 18 dollars and received eggs totally uncooked  with canadian bacon. bought to their attention and 20 minutes later received eggs benedict with cold salmon on an non toasted cold muffin. ugh

Best patio in Scottsdale for sunsets over Camelback! The food here is always top notch and the staff/service is impeccable. The Pork Tenederloin and the Short Ribs are some of the best in town. But whatever I order as main entree I'll always sub Garlic Mashed as my starch.....so good!!

It has been 1 year since I went to El Chorro. Went to Sunday brunch last week and was very disappointed. Ordered eggs Benedict and got cooked salmon on the bottom that was salty and a very small English muffin. Eggs Benedict should have lox or cured salmon . I could have cooked a better dish at home . Not worth the money. The service was good but the kitchen needs to do better at making their food worth while. The best eggs Benedict is at St. Francis on camelback rd.

Forget  this  brunch  on a special day. Mother's Day was a disaster. Seated  in a  back patio,  so could have been  anywhere. No view,  no music. Had  to ask for extra umbrella 3  times.  The food was  more than forgettable.  Eggs  Benedict on an English Muffin that could  not  be cut with a steak knife,  chicken tenders totally dried up and inedible.Bus persons left dirty dishes on table until they we  asked to have them removed.  And to top it off, American valet parking  which took up all the close spots  so that with a handicapped sticker we were obliged  to pay $5.00 parking  or walk from  back  parking lot. None of it set well, probably  the last time for  this place I used to love. Too many  other places  to choose  from.

Wow, first time back here in 15 years. Awesome meal from the house salad to the tenderloin stroganoff. Top notch every bit of the way. Tracy the manager made sure we had a great time. Will be back sooner than last time for sure.
One of our top ten meals ever.  Fabulous food, service and a beautiful setting.  Would go back anytime in the Scottsdale area.
The views from the patio are amazing! We came here for brunch and the food was great! I especially loved the bread basket! Service was great with no complaints!

I been only once, the place is beautiful & our waiter took really good care of us.  However  I felt the menu (we did brunch) was limited & they could not do special requests, I wanted to make changes to the omelet listed on the menu but was told the chef did not like that.

Thank you for your reply. 
After discussing with the party that attended we have decided to return. 

On a positive note I would like to comment on the beautiful atmosphere and the items we did order were delicious. Such as the poutine and deviled eggs.

Since 1984 we have gone to El Chorro for the best drinks with a view and have always loved everything about the charming historic setting.  It has recently been remodeled so we were excited to meet friends there to see the changes.  We should have known there was a "problem" when we pulled into the nearly empty parking lot.  The new bar area is very pretty and the view of the back of Camelback Mtn is still gorgeous.  Unfortunately, the bar menu is extremely limited and quite expensive.  In the past El Chorro was a fun, buzzing place for happy hour, but now the happy hour is limited to pricey watered down drinks and an expensive shrimp cocktail or brisket sandwich. Even the trademark cheese and crackers are gone!  We are so sad to say we will no longer take our out of state visitors to El Chorro.  Very disappointing experience and we will not be back.

Great setting, good food, terrible customer service. 
There was six of us enjoying happy hour on the patio when we were joined by a friend with a very small dog, 5lbs tops, that she was holding. As soon as she ordered her drink, the manager, Ryan (very rude person) came over and asked for the dog's papers.
If the dog isn't a service dog with papers then she could not stay. Seriously??? It's a patio at 4:30 in the afternoon. He insisted we leave. 
When we asked that her drink ( which she never had the opportunity to enjoy) be taken off the bill, his response was "I can't do that". Of course he can do that, he's the manager.  He shouldn't be!! 
Needless to say, we won't be back!!
I like the atmosphere. I took my girlfriend here. She's from NYC and really loved it. The food was okay.

We had an issue with our reservation when we first arrived (only reason for a 4 star rating) which was quickly corrected after speaking with a manager.  After that the night was fantastic.  The food was outstanding, the wine was perfect, and one of the best service experiences I have ever had.  Our server was Warner and he was outstanding.  Make sure you ask for him, I know we will when we return.  The entertainment and dancing was also a nice touch.  A perfect evening!

Maybe my expectations were too high but other than the mellow view from the patio, I wasn't overly impressed.

The place dates back to the 1930's and was remodeled in 2009 (??) The outdoor dining area has great views of Camelback Mountain.  The service is slow and the food was nothing to write home about.  I thought it was very overpriced as well.

Myself and two friends were at the restaurant for happy hour.  A friend was visiting from Germany and I suggested El Chorro, a place that we frequent with friends.  I looked at your website at 11:09am  today and copied and pasted the information from your website that said Happy hour was from 4-6 and the buffet was from 5-6.  I will copy and paste my email to my friend. (Copied at the end of this review)  We decided to meet at 4:30.  According to our watches we went to the buffet at appx 4:58 and there was nothing there.  We visited a while longer and returned at 5:08 and there was nothing but there was a sign that said as of today the buffet was from 4-5.  We went ahead and ordered but asked for the manager, Steven.  He came over but said the website was changed this morning.  I said I copied and pasted from the website today and my friend could not find the email.  I then looked through my sent and found the email.  I asked to see him again and showed him.  I really didn't want him to do anything except acknowledge that we were right...it did say that.  Instead he told me it was changed earlier in the day. I mentioned we came there often with friends and he said people got emails of the time change.  I didn't.  I just wanted him to say he was sorry for the confusion or something...he was rude.  The email is at the bottom of this email. 
The food was good but the management is bad.  He should have just apologized and said it should have been changed earlier.  


Eileen  
 

From: Marita Muhr (address deleted)
Sent: Monday, March 25, 2013 3:13 PM
To: Eileen Klecka
Subject: Re: Maybe we get there 4:30...5:00 is the free buffet

Ok,i will leave here at 4:15

Sent from my iPad

On Mar 25, 2013, at 11:09, "Eileen Klecka" eklecka@cox.net wrote:
El Chorro invites you to stop in for our fantastic happy hour! Enjoy our complimentary hors d'oeuvre buffet from 5-6 p.m. and drink specials from 4-6 p.m., ...
 
Eileen

Attended brunch for mothers day. The place was nice and the food was good. However there was cross contamination with the dishes and both my daughter and myself are vegetarians and had stomach problems as a result.

Your review helps others learn about great local businesses.

Please don't review this business if you received a freebie for writing this review, or if you're connected in any way to the owner or employees.
A friend and I enjoyed Sunday brunch at this beautiful venue today to celebrate her birthday.  We were seated on the patio and ordered the Trout Almondine which was recommended by our server, Chris.   Our drinks arrived and then the sticky buns and pastries arrived.  Nirvana!  Out came the trout which is frankly the best I have ever tasted.  So if you are looking for a fabulous meal with impeccable servic ( request Chris ) come to El Chorro!!!

Sad to say our dining experience last night was below par to say the least. We love the venue and outdoor patio and views but our dinner was more like Outback Steakhouse with a 250.00 price tag attached   We order the fried lobster tail app that came out chewy! My wife ordered the jumbo prawn dinner with risotto n asparagus, first thing my wife noticed was one of her jumbo prawns on display on top of her entree was full of poop right on front street the chef couldn't use a pooper scooper??? My steak was a ribeye for 52bucks that was thin, chewy and over cooked. All of this with no comp of any of it to make us feel at least a little better, don't see us going back for a long time!

I have been dining at El Chorro Lodge since 1974. El Chorro Lodge is a family favorite. When Joe and Evie announced there retirement and selling of El Chorro, I am grateful Mrs. Dorrance saved El Chorro from turning into Paradise Valley's next luxury home subdivision. 

First and foremost, the renovations to El Chorro are fantastic! The patios have been enlarged to take advantage of the great views of Camelback Mountain, numerous fireplaces added to add to the ambiance and the charm of El Chorro preserved in the process. Kudos to the designers for saving the copper hood of the fireplace in the old dining room and relocating it to the renovated schoolroom bar! (One sad note, miss the "Knights of the Round Table" table that was next to old fireplace on the old main patio. Its now a service area, but time marches on!) 

The entire of the new restaurant speaks of old Arizona, but in a fresh and modern way. Photos and art work of happy times at the Old El Chorro decorate the walls and is a gracious nod to the past. 

The cocktail menu has been expand, and a second bar has been added with great views of Camelback Mountain. This is a terrific place to grab an old school martini or try one of their handcrafted cocktails. 

Our dinner was graced with the old relish tray, served on a cold plate instead of chipped ice. (Chipped ice would have been a nicer presentation.) 

Appetizers include the standard shrimp cocktail, flash fried lobster tail and new additions. Soup of the day or salad is included with the dinner entree, which is a nice touch in an ala carte world. 

My girlfriend enjoyed the filet, which was tender and cooked to perfection. I enjoyed the duck breast, which was flavorful, tender and not overcooked. 

Just two notes for improvements, I don't know what happened to the original recipes for the flash-fried lobster batter or the sticky buns, but please, please look for them! Some classic items just do not need improvement! Also, $5 for valet parking, please.

Unfortunate, because we always liked this place.  It was bad from the start!  I tried to reserve the fireplace area below the TV on the back, inside patio for 15 people for happy hour, where we have sat before many times.  They said that was for dinner only.  How can you eat dinner without a table?  They said they don't take reservations for happy hour, and that is fine but they wouldn't even let us sit out there?  It was completely empty when looking at it when leaving.  

We were lucky enough to get one table large enough for us all to sit at inside near the bar area.  The manager and waitress were very rude to our party and told us we cannot save the seats at our table for our group that was coming.  They sent others there to sit with us but when the others realized that we were all one group and had more people come in without a seat, they left and expressed their opinion on how management handled that, which wasn't good.  The manager told my friend that he didn't care if we all came back or not and the waitress told me, after we received one check for 16 people, including a 20% gratuity which wasn't deserved, that she didn't care how many other places accommodated us for separate checks, they don't!  Since when?  They always did.

It is unfortunate as I said because we all loved going here regularly, including Thanksgiving eve, and were always able to sit outside around the fireplace, and always received our own checks for what we separately ordered.  What happened to this place?  Is there a new owner, or new management?  Very unprofessional staff and not accommodating at all!

Brought my parents (and friends)for 50th anniversary brunch although the sticky buns are amazing, we had complete attitude from server when we asked for more (only 2 in basket for 5 people). We had 2 rounds of drinks and full entrees. We were told that only first basket is complimentary even though menu clearly states they come with entrees. After writing email to El Chorro weeks ago with NO response...it was time to give ya'll a heads up. :)

I found El Chorro to be a wonderful restaurant on all fronts. The service from valet to table service was excellent. It was polite, timely, and smooth. I did take off a star for their bizarre and annoying valet tagging system which was the only blip in my otherwise flawless experience. My appetizers came out quickly and were quite tasty. The main course followed after just the right amount of time. The turkey was juicy and flavorful with perfect sides of mashed potatoes. I followed with cheesecake for dessert which was equally wonderful. This is a pricey restaurant, but I think the food, ambiance, and service make it worth while.

Worst server I've ever encountered. Extremely condescending to all four of us. Our out of town friends were excited to come to the restaurant, and definitely loved the setting. Waiter appeared to not want to do his job. He couldn't pronounce seafood of the day (Ono - said he didn't care and pronounced it Uno), was very unfriendly when it came to recommendations or answering basic questions. If I ever return, I'd demand another server.
Ordered brisket beef sandwich - inedible, stringy and fatty. BLT salad small for $7 and very average. Would not return

El Chorro sits right on the backside of Camelback mountain and has a southwestern decor and gorgeous patio.  Casual dress or a nice dress could be worn here.  The menu has a variety of options.  We started off with a shrimp pot dish and it was deelish.  My entree was trout almondine with green beans ( ordered a separate side of scalloped potatoes also)  My dish was prepared perfectly and didn't walk out feeling overly stuffed (like my usual) so I felt pretty good about myself for having the self discipline to not order a dessert.  Sit on the patio if you can!!!!
The goal is to open doors, not close them. To gain engagement and productive interaction, not to have the customer become enraged and walk away.

I'm not sure what happened - but they made us drink a lot of whiskey!  In all seriousness, we were there f the Whiskey Cocktail School. This special event features 11 (count them) ELEVEN American whiskies complete with Alec's excellent instruction. A great night out- including a delicious braised beef ribs and chile pepper risotto. I would give this 10 stars- but for a couple suggestions. Or I would make it 4 & 15/16 stars...  They brought the infamous sticky buns at the beginning - but after much whiskey drinking only the dinner came. I would complement the tasting with some small appetizers. Also I would add a small cheese course and a small chocolate dessert for the end tastings. Great restaurant that I can tell has owners who care and are present. You can ALWAYS tell the difference. Check out the website for a rocking happy hour too.

I was very excited about the re-opening of El Chorro.  I always felt it was a great location that was hampered by a boring menu and a tired looking restaurant.  There is no doubt that the property and build-out was money well spent.  It is a gorgeous restaurant.  It is a shame that they didn't put the same amount of money and effort into training their staff on service and execution.

We ordered the shrimp cocktail and the cheese plate which was $18 for 4 store bought crackers, 2 small, thin pieces of cheese and 4 small, thin slices of salami.  The salads were horrendous - the vegetable chopped salad was a rectangular plate with little rows of potato, celery, carrot, walnuts and cranberries - all totally oversalted and just not appetizing.  The signature steak and onion soup was gelatinous and lukewarm.  (They mistakenly brought the baked potato soup first which had an oatmeal consistency.) And by the way, according to our server we were allowed to order whatever salads we wanted to go with our entrees.  At the end there were upcharges on the bill for the non "house" salads.  
 
We never received rolls or sticky buns (after asking twice) and they finally brought sticky buns out when the entrees were plated.  In addition, we did not have bread and butter plates and the utensils were not replenished.   My friend's $40+ steak was ordered medium rare, yet came out well done.  He ordered no starch so they brought him a plate of carrots!  I ordered "double vegetable" with my chicken instead of starch and I literally had 4 snow peas and 3 green beans on the plate.   My spouse ordered the duck and the side dish it came with was absolutely disgusting - some kind of pomegranate-y starch thing that had a sour taste.   My friend sent the steak back and it came out bloody and rare - and with starch on the plate.  That one was sent back and the chef himself brought out the third one - with starch.  They bought us a round of desserts (the molten cake was cooked through so it was basically a warm brownie) and took the steak off the bill.  

I would return for drinks but not for the food.

Yes, the sticky buns are great.

My grandparents would think this was one of the best restaurants in the world.  The menu is very old-school with rich, heavy dishes.  We started with the recommended shrimp pepper pot.  It was delicious, but we both commented on how heavy the butter seemed in the dish, and how it could have been lightened up with a little olive oil.  The house salad was romaine lettuce with a sherry vinegarette.  Again, a more modern menu would probably use different greens.  Our entrees were huge - my prime rib was cooked nicely but lacked a little seasoning. My wife had the fish special: halibut in hollindaise sauce.  Again, huge portion, very rich.  Coffee was very watery and reminded me of dinners at grandmas house.

The patio is amazing with beautiful views. The menu a throwback to an earlier generation of "fine dining." it was nostalgic to eat food like this, but i doubt we'll come back.

This is a TRUE five start restaurant. Our party of three was two out-of-towners and one local who was new to the area. We had El Chorro recommended to us by friends in Mesa. A short wait at the bar and we were seated on the patio and had a great server.

We had short ribs, seafood pasta and trout almondine with mussels for an appetizer. The seafood pasta and mussels were a bit overkill on seafood, but I am a seafood lover and loved it all. 

The new Paradise Valley member of our group (fresh out of college) loved it as well as us older folks and plans to return as soon as she can. All and all a wonderful evening out. We have added it to our must visit in Phoenix list.

This place is amazing. It has gorgeous scenery, friendly and efficient service, good food, and a great happy hour. They must do a lot of weddings here because it's provides the beauty of the desert landscape and great space for a ceremony, cocktail, hour and reception, all with the privacy that you would not have getting married at one of the nearby resorts. 

Their happy hour is awesome. $2.00 beers, killer tacos, a great burger. I think we spent $25 for the both of us to eat dinner and have a few drinks. It's a great place to take a date or have a romantic night. We are definitely going back.
Can never go wrong with eggs Benedict, I've never tried a vegetarian style before and it was actually very delightful on my appetite and health :)

I went to El Chorro last Thursday night for the first time since Joe Miller sold the restaurant and I was disappointed with my food but it was only one meal and I never will condemn a restaurant from one meal. However, if you are looking for atmosphere of Paradise Valley then it is a great spot to go especially now that the snowbirds are back in town.
excellent food and great atmosphere.  We sat outside and the view was spectacular.  will go again when I'm in Phoenix again.

Went for dinner with my husband and parents before they fly back to France. Perfect dinner, perfect setting, service was excellent. I highly recommend El Chorro if you want to enjoy both the food and the setting in a calm and serene setting. The cheese and charcuterie platter is more about cheese than charcuterie but other than, the short ribs are excellent (really) and the trout was well appreciated by a picky french eater. The bar tender was very knowledgeable. Perfect evening.

As we waited for our table we could see the sun setting over the mountains while drinking a solid glass of wine. 

Then we sat down in this beautiful restaurant where they brought out these cinnamon buns instead of bread. YUM. I was almost hooked on this place.

We ordered the burrata appetizer and it was done perfectly. We couldn't wait for our entree.

Then it came. We had ordered the lamb which came over a mashed potato type side. I couldn't even eat it. It was not good at all. The lamb was overcooked and lacked flavor. The side underneath it had a weird aftertaste. It was so disappointing. Everyone at our table agreed that their meals were also a letdown. The night was leading up to this phenomenal meal and it let us down. Maybe this was an isolated incident, but maybe this place survives on it's beauty and location.

Beautiful restaurant with a wonderful front of the house staff and just average food that is overpriced for the quality.  The menu descriptions are enticing but the dishes themselves just lack flavor.  If they delivered the taste they described then the prices would make sense.

Ate there last night. The service was beyond bad. Had to wait 35 minutes for our waiter to take our order  but only after we had to ask someone else to get him. He said we were talking so he didn't want to interrupt-  wow! Had to ask for the cinnamon rolls that they bring as bread before dinner.Food took forever to come. We were outside and had heaters but they were pointing  away from table so we asked for the heater s to be pointed at table. waiter said he look into it but never happened. Then on top of the bad service, because we were a party of six, there was an automatic 20% tip and they have the nerve to ask for additional tip. Why does a party of six take more work than three tables of two. This place is a snow birders trap. Second time we have had bad service and mediocre food. Won't be back and would recommend others avoid them

I really don't get the negative reviews, understand you can have a single bad experience at any restaurant, but if you frequent El Chorro you know it's outstanding. 

Went last night for birthday dinner:
Atmosphere: 5 Stars
Service: 5 Stars
Food: 4.5 Stars 

Outdoor dining at its finest in Arizona, service was impeccable.  Knowledgeable server, outstanding assistance with wine selection, prompt curious and friendly.  Drinks never empty, food served promptly, and cleared immediately, but never rushed.  Day before they call to confirm reservation and preferred seating; day after they even follow-up with a phone call for your feedback on your dining experience.

Signature sticky buns served timely, warm and delicious.  Wine and bourbon old fashion were great, started with crab cakes which were made to perfection.  Shrimp and beef stroganoff entrees well seasoned, served piping hot and very good, tenderloin was melt in your mouth tender.  I indicted birthday on open table reservation, but did not say anything to wait staff or hostess when they called the day prior; however, we were served a free white chocolate desert complete with candle....nice touch.  

If you haven't tried El Chorro, it rates as top 10 food destination in Phoenix, don't miss it!

This was rated BEST eggs benedict. I unfortunately can not agree ONLY because the price was just outrageous! $16! The location was about 20 miles away from down town Phoenix located in a ritzy dirt road area that was fairly easy to find. The interior seemed upper class mid 90's. The waiter was attentive and the sticky buns served as appetizers were just as appealing as they were delicious. Would ONLY recommend if the price was lower and the location wasn't a day drive.

There have been many positive reviews for this place, but definitely not my kind of place.

First the positive: The outside patio is lovely.

But the negative outweighed the positive for me:  There are no vegetarian dishes on the happy hour menu. The server did tell me there were vegetarian dishes on the main menu, but the only thing that looked vegetarian was the tomato  burrata salad I it was terrible and over-priced. El Chorro would do better to serve the traditional caprese salad. I did not eat the salad.  It was supposed to be served with crostini, but I never received that either. I did ask for some bread and the server acted like it was unusual but finally served me some old, hard sour dough bread. Definitely not going here again.

Sorry El Chorro, I found the service lacking and the food worse.

We were extremely disappointed today. We were seated at a very nice table and preparing to order. Prior to a server accepting an order, someone from the hostess podium came to our table and told us we would have to move; the table was reserved. I stated that we had a reservation. She stated that the particular table we occupied was reserved for some one else. We were then moved to an "ok" location in the restaurant. My husband is a cancer patient and being moved was a chore. No one cared. Food was good as was service. Guess certain patrons are more important than others. Very disappointed in the pretentiousness.

BEWARE OF BAD SERVER named Angei.  (6) of us attempted to have a nice meal at El Chorro last night to kick off the first day of Arizona Restaurant Week.  This was my second visit to El Chorro and the first for everyone else.

Our server Angei appeared to be in her first hour of being employed as a server and kicked off the worst night of dining in my life by being completely clueless about Gluten allergies (my sister-in-law has a Gluten allergy).  The restaurant week menu specifically stated that there were Gluten-free options.  When we asked which options were Gluten-free she had no idea what was Gluten-free on the restaurant week menu or the regular  Gluten-free menu.   We sent her off to the kitchen to in quire about the Gluten-free option.  She came back to our table twice more in the next (20) minutes with no answer other than "We were told the only Gluten-free option was the vegetarian pasta."   She actually had the nerve to ask us what would be in their own dishes that would contain Gluten.  How on earth are we to know how they prepare the menu.  She claimed that she had spoken to the chef but she obviously made that story up.

After these (2) attempts we finally demanded that she send a manager to our table.  (10) minutes later the manager arrived armed with the Gluten-free menu for El Chorro to help eliminate the confusion.  As he learned from us the confusion was on the part of Angei who had never brought us a Gluten-free menu even though we looked it up on the restaurant's own website and showed her this evidence on our iPhones.  She claimed the Gluten-free status must have been a misprint.

By this point we are now (45) minutes into the dining experience and just placing our order.  Fast forward another (45) minutes and after a combined hour and a half our young children are now starving and fussy because they are tired of sitting in a restaurant.   My wife and the (2) young children had to leave before the first course even arrived.  When departing my wife went to the front hostess and complained about the poor quality of the service and asked a manager to look into this.  No one ever came by to check on us the balance of evening.  Had they done so we would have shared our experience with them in vivid detail.  We then had everything thereafter boxed table side because Angei stated it was too difficult for the kitchen to box up the courses for my wife.  Even that process was difficult to communicate as we had to remind her to bring additional boxes and tell her it would be inadvisable to place a scoop of ice cream in a cardboard box with a hot piece of chocolate cake that we would attempt to rush to my wife (at home starving with two young kids) 30 minutes away.

Before the main course arrived she came to the table bearing news that they were out of the dessert feature we had ordered and told us they had a chocolate torte (which turned out to be a chocolate lava cake) and then asked which dessert we would like to choose.  We didn't have a choice but the torte so why ask us which option we prefer.  Torte or nothing?

When we finally received dessert my sister-in-law with the Gluten allergy thought she would enjoy the ice cream only on her dessert plate only to find that whatever utensil had been used to dish the ice cream had been previously used to dish something with a cake or cookie consistency thereby cross-contaminating Gluten into her ice cream which will most likely make her very ill in the upcoming hours.  

Angei had (3) tables.  (2) were 2-tops and ours was a 6-top that became a 3-top.  Every single request (water, soda, etc.) took (10) minutes minimum to be fulfilled.  Our table was collecting spent plates, glasses, etc. that never left our sight.

The simplest of instructions seemed to be received as complex to Angei as diffusing a bomb.  We repeated our requests and answered her questions more than once on several occasions.

At the end of the night we requested that my brother and his wife have a separate check than my family only to be told that they did not have that ability but if we told her how much to put on each credit card she could do that.  She didn't seem to understand that was the same exact outcome with the only difference being that we would be responsible for sitting at the table and calculating our own bills.

The food was very good from first course to dessert but the service was the worst I have received in my life.  This individual should have been set free in a sit down restaurant where the meals were $5.00 on average.  Instead we averaged $50.00 per person and could have received better service from the bus boys.

I know that this is probably the first real weekend for the outdoor patio seating at El Chorro which looks like it doubles their capacity so perhaps Angei is one of the new players on the team, but it is completely unacceptable that any patrons, particularly first time visitors during restaurant week, be treated to sub-par service like this.
Alisha was a pleasure to be around. She gave great service and a happy smile:) delicious food and drinks!!! The cinnamon rolls will have me coming back soon!

You must try Happy Hour at El Chorro. The drinks are great, and so is the food offered. I had Wine (which by the way for a house wine it was really good) . I ordered the sliders that came with a load of fries really delicious. Not to mention the wait staff was so obliging and friendly.  The view was breathtaking,, since Camelback mountain is right at your front door. Great evening out,, and the bill??? very reasonable.  Trust me try this place,, you will love it.  I will be going back for Dinner very soon,,,maybe I will include the Happy Hour as well.

Another awesome evening at El Chorro. Had friends in town from Philly and they couldn't stop raving about the ambiance, food and staff.  Salmon, Seafood Pasta and Pork Tenderloin just to name a few were spectacular.  Of course, the Cheese and Charcuterie platter along with Shriners sausage appetizers, are by far, the best in town. Can't say enough about Ryan and his team. Excellent evening.  Thank you.

My husband and I recently visited El Chorro and it was by far one of the best dinning experiences we have had. We previously had made reservations a few weeks back for the South Patio. From the moment we arrived the front desk staff up to the Management were extremely professional and friendly. We ordered the pan roasted giant shrimp for our appetizer and the seasonal wild salmon and short ribs for our entrees. They were delicious!! We especially enjoyed the sticky buns. El Chorro has the most beautiful patio dining and friendly staff, and we look forward to coming back soon.
The patio atmosphere and stars are beautiful. The short ribs were fantastic and the wedge salad too. The Prisoner Red wine blend was amazing along with the service from Trent.

We came to El Chorro to celebrate my boyfriend's birthday and it was amazing! We sat on the patio next to a fireplace - very romantic. I had the trout almondine and the boy had the filet - YUM! The service was attentive and friendly,  the birthday dessert was delicious and enough to share. If you get a chance, try the Gin Rickey cocktail - almost too easy to drink ;) We can't wait to come back!

Attended the Paso Robles wine tasting event here last night. The room the wine tasting was held in was arranged to provide good spacing and flow. You could get around to each winery's station and not be too crowded. That was the best part.

However the food was set up outside and as it got later and darker, no provision was made to light the food stations. You could not read the signs identifying the dish - nor could you see the food. I would have expected the foresight to light it up outside, especially over the food pans and buffet. The food was very good, but we had to use our iPhones to see the food, including 5 or 6 different hummus flavors.
It was all finger foods and we could not find napkins to clean up after eating the short ribs and mashed potatoes or the chicken.

Good food, bad planning for a buffet.

I have so many wonderful feelings, and delicious experiences at el choreographed. So much that we are actually planning our wedding here ! From their sticky buns to jalepeno polenta, melt in your mouth short rib and buttery goodness lamb... Your experience will be outstanding every time.

Great outdoor patio with lots of fireplaces and twinkly lights! The atmosphere was the highlight of the evening. 
We had the wedge salad and Caesar salad. Both were excellent. 
I had the giant shrimp for my entree and it was great! My husband had the chicken and it was just okay. It had kind of a bitter undertone that he didn't like. 
The sticky buns are amazing!!

We have gone to El Chorro 3 to 4 times in the last 2 years and each time, the service and food was excellent.  We like their menu and always find something different to eat that we like.

Last time, I had the Santa Barbara Mussels for an appetizer, which were excellent.  This time, we had the cheese and charcuterie plate.  For two people, it was more than enough.  I thought they were a bit skimpy with the charcuterie they offered and I was not impressed with the cheeses they offered - a blue cheese, cheddar, triple cream and perhaps manchego, which was the tastiest.

For dinner, I had the seafood pasta. Again, it was pretty tasty although they again were a bit skimpy with the seafood.  They only put three mussels in the seafood and clams were few in number as well.

The two other people in my party enjoyed the food more and enjoyed their fillet and rack of lamb..

When we go back next time, I will stick to the mussels for an appetizer and the fillet, and maybe one day, I will save room for desert.

Again great service and ambience on the patio is fantastic.

Let's get one thing straight, the location and setting is wonderful. Most of the cuisine was cooked, seasoned, and presented well with satisfying portions. 

(restaurant week menu) - Watermelon, Tomato, & Jicama Salad, Polenta & Vegetable Napoleon, and strawberry shortcake. 
(regular menu) - Shrimp pepper pot and Beef Stroganoff 

The highlights on the food include the Beef Stroganoff (the fresh pasta and the sauce was superb) and the Polenta & Vegetable Napoleon (beautiful dish and vegetables were cooked nicely). The sauce on the shrimp pepper pot was flavorful but felt there was way too much bread served and would have preferred if the shrimp tails would have been pulled off. In addition, the salad and the strawberry shortcake was nothing to rave about. 

Now onto the service. It was hugely underwhelming. For a fine establishment to have their patrons push aside their finished plates (pre-bus) for the staff and not have one our water glasses refilled throughout the entire dining experience was a vast disappointment and inexcusable. Our plates were not picked up until the next course arrived. We do not blame our server since she was occupied with other tables (who all were sat at about the same time) but there were multiple staff members around who completely zoned us out. Why bother when it isn't your table right? 

All in all, El Chorro had tremendous potential but we left dissatisfied with the experience and will keep El Chorro off our list of restaurants in Scottsdale. Plenty of other high-quality restaurants to spend $150+ in Scottsdale/Phoenix.

When you first arrive at El Chorro, expectations are high because of its location, it's valet ($6) service, and its entrance/atmosphere. 

However, the restaurant fell short due to its food (mainly the appetizers) for its price. 

For our table of 9, i think we ordered about 5 appetizers. Because sharing is caring, I had a chance to try all of them. To be honest, i wasn't not impressed by most of them. I felt the fried items tasted fried. The sausage bites weren't anything special. The pretzel bread it came with are sliced and weren't soft as pretzel bread usually is by the time i got ahold of them. The foie gras was pretty good, but it came with 3 or so mini pieces of toast. The board wasn't bad, but again for a $30 price tag...I'm not sold. 

As for the entrees, I ended up getting an vegetarian dish (polenta) and I added a protein to it, which was suggested by the waitress. I liked the polenta dish a lot and its flavors. It outshined the salmon i ordered with it. And the only thing I knew about El Chollo before coming was it had great sticky buns. These we had to ask for, and they were pretty good - just a little sweet but expected. I can't speak for the other entrees, but I heard the lamb was tender and it fell off the shank and the prime rib was good, cooked to asked temperature. 

Overall my personal experience is a 3 star because I don't think I would come back as the prices don't justify the food or service. There are other nice comparable options.

Wow! Great meal on Saturday night. It is definately pricier than it used to be under old ownership - pre-remodel, but it is absolutely lovely, the food is above average (not the best for the prices imo) the view is stunning. The service is on point - just enough not too much. We were celebrating our anniversary and they brought us a lovely dessert. Also, hostess called us the day after to thank us for our visit and inquire about our experience. Really nice touch - so easy for a restaurant to do this and go the extra mile, but really no one does anymore. Kudos to the service team.

Attended a friend's wedding here this past weekend and I cannot say enough great things about it.  I can't speak for the restaurant since we were in the back hall for special events, but for a wedding it was perfect!   Gorgeous atmosphere and scenery.  There was TONS of space for the ceremony, outdoor cocktail hour and the reception inside with a decent sized dance floor!  Also it felt very private so no restaurant patrons around or cutting through, which is a plus in my book.  I would highly recommend as a place to get hitched!  Now I just need to come back to AZ so I can test out the restaurant.

The food is fabulous and the ambiance is fantastic. This is a great place to meet friends for lunch and the views. Dinner here is so nice and romantic. Don't forget to bring your winter visitors here for lunch, they will love the food and rave about the setting!

THE STICKY BUNS ARE SO GOOD!

Seriously though, my fiance and I went to El Chorro for Sunday brunch this morning and we loved it. The restaurant is beautiful, offering stunning views of Camelback and Mummy Mountain. Dining is available inside, or covered outside seating with portable air conditioners. We chose to dine inside.

When we sat down we were immediately served some fresh sticky buns and croissants. The sticky buns were warm, gooey, and delicious, everything you could want in a sticky bun. We each ordered a mimosa that seemed to be the perfect balance of orange juice and champagne.

My fiance ordered the two eggs for breakfast, which came with bacon, potatoes, and an arugula salad. I ordered the omelette of the day, which was a carne asade omelette with peppers and mushrooms. The omelette also came with potatoes and salad.

Overall we were very pleased with the food and service. The wait staff was super friendly, the front desk was super friendly, we felt at home. El Chorro highly recommended for anyone looking for an upscale brunch experience complete with sticky buns.

We're visiting from Las Vegas and "what a wonderful find!" Met our neighbors from California who live in Scottsdale and had a wonderful meal in addition to tasty cocktails ( enjoyed the Passionate Mule so much I had 2) and a super server, Julia ~
   The sticky bun are good, seemed odd for dinner but I had no trouble devouring mine. My husbands beet salad looked pretty and tasted as good as it looked. The Halibut was the special of the day and was also quite! QUITE!! delicious and presentation was suburb. The Fried Lobster good with really good remoulade sauce + butter, YUM!
  We skipped dessert, enjoyed coffee/cappuccinos, walked around the stunning grounds, enjoyed the numerous fireplaces, and western decor.
     Just a great, great evening if your any where near Paradise Valley, El Chorro should be a "MUST" stop ~

I had brunch with my family on the patio at El Chorro this morning, and I was quite disappointed with this landmark restaurant.  We sat on the patio - which was absolutely beautiful (and the reason this rating gets any stars!)  and had an amazing view of Camelback Mountain.  There was also a fair amount of heaters and fireplaces, so it would be nice to sit out there in colder weather, too. 

It was pretty fun to people watch here - everyone was so expensive looking! And, at 23, I think I was the youngest person there by a solid 15 years. 

The service here was extremely sub-par, especially considering the prices they charge.  We were greeted with a "you have reservations, don't you?!"  No, we don't. And now you just made us feel like we did something wrong by not making them - even though there was plenty of seating!  We were seated right away, regardless. 

And, it goes downhill from there. The waiter was unfamiliar with the menu and had to have us point to several items on the menu.  The bus staff that brought us our food had quite a hard time reading the ticket that told them who ordered what, it would have been much faster to ask, "who had the french toast?!"  I was brought the wrong dish, and when it came out the second time, the eggs weren't cooked how I asked.  It took a good 15 minutes to get our credit card back from the waiter after we had given it to him to pay.  I tried to give the staff a little credit, because this place is brand new - but you think in this economy they could hire some experienced wait staff! 

I thought the prices were ridiculous - $6 for a side of 2 eggs?! $13 for a fruit bowl!? Ouch.

As much I would like to come back for drinks on the patio at sunset, I don't think I can justify dealing with the staff and prices again.

We went for my birthday back in March and it was perfect! We sat on the patio with a beautiful view of camelback mountain and shared an incredible meal! The wine was delicious, the sticky buns are incredible! My boyfriend got the salad and I got soup before sharing the chateaubriand for two! Wow. I like med rare, Johnny likes medium, it came out perfect for both of us! Plus the veggies! Delicious. Then came the dessert and since it was my birthday we got two! 
Everyone needs to try to save room for dessert! I promise you will not be disappointed! 

Oh and keep those sticky buns coming!!!

The food here is mediocre at best. We went for brunch, and the eggs are spongy and horrible. They taste like they were cracked a week ago. I'm not sure why older establishments cannot keep up with the times. The manager should go to Matt's Big Breakfast to see what fresh food tastes like. The service was just as bad as the food. A few people had requests, I.e medium cooked poached eggs, etc. None of it was honored; it seemed like the waitress didn't even bother to write anything down. I ordered an omelette and specified gluten free (the menu says to specify). It showed up with an English muffin right on top. But I don't think that was the only gluten because fast forward an hour and I'm sick. Perhaps the potatoes or the pork filling in the omelette. Perhaps if the manager reads this, he will get a clue. The two stars is only for the beautiful patio and decent coffee.

Came here for quick brunch after church since its right next door. Great atmosphere and location but that's all this place has going for it. Service is bad. Food is bad. Water was empty. 

We ordered the burger and Benedict.  We asked for bacon on the side for the burger, but that is not how it came. Its okay we took the bacon off, and put it on the side ourselves. Strike 1. The fries were great though. 

Benedict was terrible. It was not even warm when it came out. Sauce was mediocre. The potatoes were the only good thing of this dish. 

The kitchen staff came and brought gravy on the side. I did not order this and he left it here for me. It was an awkward three minute exchange. I had began to try it since they brought it out and the waiter came rushing out and grabbed it and said this was not for me. And headed to other side of the bar and handed it to the lady EVEN THOUGH I DIPPED MY FORK IN IT AND ATE IT!!!!!! I was appalled. The man next to me noticed as well and was just as shocked as I was. 

Never got my water refilled a single time. Same with my friend. Just ate our food and stayed parched with nothing to quench our thirst. It also took 15 min for them to collect our payment. 

Stay away from here.

We had reservations for brunch at 10:30 and were seated immediately next to the cutest fireplace facing the mountains. Our server was fantastic and very attentive. He was very knowledgeable about the menu and gave great suggestions. I had the parfait with fruit and bread from the starters menu. The parfait was incredible. It had strawberries, blueberries, bananas, granola and fresh honey. That was my favorite. The fruit was nice with cantaloupe, grapes, pineapple and honeydew. The bread was ok but a bit dry. I preferred the roll basket they gave at the beginning with the sticky rolls, a scone, and a croissant.

The grounds and atmosphere were beautiful. We explored a bit after and found it was set up for a wedding. I had to share a picture of the cute getaway Jeep!
I don't get Heather D.  An omelette, hash browns and an English muffin?  Anyone can make that at home.  El Chorro is an overpriced mediocre place.  You can't eat views.

This is a place that will go down in memory book. Cinnamon buns to die for, lobster corn bisque soup perfectly balanced & seasoned, steak cooked exactly medium rare , lobster mouse in puffed pastry. Our server Robert was great, attentive while not being intrusive. Thank you for a great dining experience

Review is for brunch only.

The location of atmosphere at El Chorro is awesome, especially on a wonderful Sunday afternoon in the spring.  Decided to try out El Chorro for brunch and was pleasantly surprised by the awesome patio we were able to experience.  The weather was awesome, so it really added to the experience.  Thanks to a reservation, we were sat immediately.  Service was great, our waiter was friendly and helpful... so nothing to complain about there.

I had the tenderloin eggs benedict and the Hubs for the chicken enchilada with egg on top (basically huevos rancheros).  We both also partook in the mimosa.  I really enjoyed my eggs benedict and opted for the half portion.  This was just enough food for me, but I could see it being not enough for most people.  At $18 I really felt gipped.  The Hubs liked his meal, but decided at the end he really wasn't in the mood for what he ordered... would have preferred the enormous breakfast burrito we saw walk by.  At $60 bucks for our breakfast we both walked away feeling a bit disappointed.  The sticky bun is just as fabulous and people say it is, but that and the scenery don't make up for the expensive price tag in my book.

I'm really glad we experienced this gem of a location and of course the sticky bun, I only wish it wasn't so darn expensive...

I was extremely disappointed with our brunch today. Our party of 6 was celebrating a couple birthdays at a restaurant that, in the past, we'd had nothing but praise. The dissatisfaction started with $6 valet parking in a parking lot that blocks off all paved parking for valet. In a town where people wear sandals year round, have to shake pebbles out of your shoes before entering the restaurant isn't fun. Upon being seated, our waitress took a few of our drink orders while the rest needed time to decide. Brought those drinks quickly, then disappeared for a while. Eventually returned to take our order. Decided to try the Tangerine Freeze, a very decent shake, with booze, that tastes just like an orange push-up. It would have been nice had the person that prepared the drinks, also wiped all the ice cream of the outside of the glass so you could pick it up without getting sticky fingers. One of our dining companions wanted the breakfast flat bread, but can't have cheese. This proved a problem because all the flatbreads, every single one in the kitchen, were already prepped with cheese. Fine, orders something else. The omelette special was a ribeye steak with grilled onions and peppers. Came out, and actually looking like an omelette, instead of over cooked unscrambled eggs, a plus, but was barely warm and the steak was completely over-cooked and leathery. The avocado BLT tasted ok, but the bacon was soggy, cold, and far removed from crisp. The biscuit and sausage gravy was very disappointing; biscuits dry and tough, gravy cold and stingy. Most of the breakfasts included an English muffin, which was cold, soaked in butter, and not really toasted much at all. The potatoes where giant chunks of potato that had been deep fried, while seasoned nicely, they also were not crispy, actually almost soggy, and not remotely cooked all the way through. As others have noted, server attentiveness seems to fall off as the meal progressed. 

Overall, I don't expect any in our group to return. It's apparent that the remodel a few years ago, not only took away the homey essence, but removed the kitchen from any semblance of providing warm, let alone hot food. An ignoble end, to what was once a great restaurant with an awesome view, and turned it into a restaurant simply going through the motions and charging a premium for subpar food.

I have dined here for Sunday brunch a few times and was always impressed, but I finally got round to having dinner here last month. And...OH MY GOSH. Without a doubt one of my favorite dining experiences in Phoenix. My parents were visiting from out of town and I wanted to wow them with somewhere fantastic, El Chorro did not disappoint. We sat outside on the patio - what a great setting with some great music playing in the background.  Our server was fantastic (I wish I remembered his name, shame on me!). It was restaurant week and the $39 for an appt, entree and dessert was a steal of a deal, but we opted for the regular menu. A little pricey, but worth every penny. The sticky buns are to die for. El Chorro is the total package and I will, without a doubt, be going back there very soon.

I came here for my friends birthday celebration and it was perfect! It was a nice quiet setting and the food was delicious! It is pricey but the food was totally worth it! The service was stellar. Our waiter, Philip, consistently checked on us. He was great! I will definitely come back!

I went to El Chorro for the first time last Saturday night. When we arrived at 5pm, there were 3 separate weddings occurring on the property - along with the regular dinner guests. That was the first 'red flag.' In my opinion, a venue cannot feel intimate (especially for a wedding) with that many other people around you.

We sat at the bar to try the happy hour menu. We ordered the twisted deviled eggs, the fish tacos, the perfect storm and the truffle fries. And sadly, we were unimpressed. The deviled eggs were deep fried and the fish tacos were served with a cheap white fish. The calamari was decent, but could have been cooked a tad longer. Which left the truffle fries.. and those were actually good! But it's hard to mess up truffle fries. 

I hear the main dinner menu is much better. And they are known for their infamous 'beer burro'. I would be willing to go back to El Chorro to try the main menu, the sticky buns and see the burro. But right now I don't think it's worth all the hype.

Beautiful venue, but inexcusable, sloppy mistakes with their food. I would have only given 1 star if they didn't do the right thing, which was comp our meal.
My husband and I went out for dinner on Christmas Day. I spent a lot of time researching places that were open. We didn't want a buffet, but we would have been better off at Denny's.

First, they sat us outside as it was a beautiful day. The fire was crackling, it was wonderful, except that our table was right next to where all the service staff hung out, so we could hear them talking. Much more desirable tables were all around us and empty during the entire 2 hours we were there.

Second, our onion soup was brought out lukewarm. When we find someone to bring us another, I don't get a soup spoon and no one offers ground pepper.

Third, the main course: my turkey and mashed potatoes are lukewarm and my husband's filet is well-done! They take both plates back and start over. It's fixed -- although I swear the mashed potatoes are right out of a box.

Fourth, I order pecan tart, and it tastes like something brought in from the frozen food section of Safeway. It doesn't taste like anything I'd serve at home.

All this for $70 per person + taxes and tip! I would never go back to that restaurant. It's a shame because it's so pretty, but it's beauty is just skin deep.

This was a great place for Sunday brunch on a beautiful spring day. We sat at the outdoor bar, rather than wait for a table, with no reservations.  The hot ham & cheese breakfast sandwich was delicious. Good service too. This place is a true 'valley of the sun' classic.

such a blast from the past,
i used to come here long ago as a child, when the previouse owner joe had the place, only the fondest memories here, the food was as always very good,
from the fillet,to the desert and the amazing sticky buns,
i have only been back a few times since the new ownership, happy to see them doing well. i remember every week friday night dinner for years was always at El chorro. lines always out the door a sense of family youd be waitting in line for a table when a friend sitting at another table would invite you to join them.
fantastic memories, set in an amazing  surrounding, at this long standing favorite gem.

Gorgeous setting and atmosphere but the happy hour was sub par. The margarita (which didn't come in a margarita glass) was $5 and didn't taste good at all. Probably the worst margarita I have had in every way. I had the sticky buns (cinnamon buns) for $5 which were tasty and the best part of the experience. The $7 kobe beef sliders (only 2 for $7) were sad, there was very little meat and mainly just a bun with a tomato slice and pickle. Definitely not a good deal. They didn't come with fries either. $3 domestic bottled beers is nothing to write home about.  All in all I would not go back here for happy hour and probably won't give the full menu a shot.

The new, old El Chorro Lodge has been reopened for all of two days, and a friend of a friend managed to secure a reservation during their soft opening, so I got an opportunity to check it out.  I was impressed, but not blown away.  Everything I tasted was quite competent, but if I had to choose a word to describe the menu, I would suggest "staid."  Perhaps even "stodgy," but that may be more harsh than I intend.

Review the dinner menu.  http://bit.ly/aWqVVJ.  There, see what I mean?  Replete with Traditional American entrees and sides, at what I would consider fairly exorbitant prices.  I would say that I wouldn't go back to eat this food at these prices, unless someone else was paying.  

I should note that a big part of why I wasn't impressed is because this place is simply not my style.  The wait staff, attired in khakis and blue shirts, was a little too informal for the prices we were paying, I felt.  The menu options were a little boring for my taste.  The cocktail menu is exactly not what I'm looking for these days, although I will be very interested to see what Happy Hour looks like.  The decor is a tad heavy on the Old Southwest theme, although to be fair, this place not only pulls it off rather stylishly but also is among the most authentically old and southwestern establishments in the Phoenix metro area.  

The patio and open bar are fantastic.  The bar area is considerable, and the patio is palatial - up above Lincoln Dr enough to be fairly quiet, with a gorgeous view of Camelback, sunset here must be incredible.  

Anyway, back to the food.  Everything was very well executed, from the sticky buns we were served upon being seated to the desserts we ordered.  I chose the soup of the day to start, a tomato/basil concoction that was quite hearty and thoroughly enjoyed it.  The salads my dining companions ate looked boring to me, but they all claimed them to be excellent, with "the best Caesar dressing ever" and "polenta croutons?!?" being the verdict for the Caesar salad, at least.  On to the entrees.  I ordered the crispy duck, which I found to be delicious and quite hearty, though not what I would call crispy by any means.  It was a very sizable portion, and very well prepared.  My dining companions ordered the pork chop, the lamb, and the salmon, and we each sampled from each other's plates.  I would try the lamb if I went back, but the consensus seemed to be that everything was very well prepared, with the duck being a winner.  It was served with a heap of mushy sweet potatoes (just like my mom makes at Thanksgiving - delicious!) and red cabbage, which I sampled and declined to finish.  Again, not quite my style.  

We moved on to dessert - sticky bread pudding with a bourbon glaze and the warm chocolate cake.  The bread pudding was a winner at the first two or three bites, but grew one-dimensional as I continued nibbling at it.  The chocolate cake was decadent, among the best I've ever tasted.  It was clearly made with a considerable amount of dark chocolate, which seals the deal for me.  And in case you were wondering, my dining companions apparently have no stamina when it comes to dessert.  Suckers.  

Anyway, as I've said now several times, this place is just not quite me.  It's totally classy and very high in quality, but not quite adventurous enough for my taste.  I'd love to come back for brunch, and once they unveil their happy hour menu, I'm sure I'll be back to check it out, but I won't be back for dinner unless I can convince someone else to pick up the check at the end of the evening.  

As a side note, this place is so very Paradise Valley.  It's a welcome relief knowing that there is a place that is so anti-scene out there.  It's been a little while since I've been both the youngest and among the poorest in a room, and I will say it was a little comforting.  Just don't tell the Scottsdale people about this place, and we'll all be happy.
Went for Restaurant Week, had the Perfect Table, view of Camelback, GREAT service and will be back. . .

A bit stuffy for my taste... 

I went there for dinner, so brunch may be a different story.  The waitress was a sweetheart and able to accommodate my food allergies, so no complaints there, but the crowd is a bit "old fashioned" to put it nicely.  Jaws agape and staring when a young couple walked in and the girls shoulders were bare. How dare she... I can only imagine their blatant stares come summer once people are in less clothing due to the 120 degree heat!

El Chorro has amazing views of Camelback Mountain, and is a solid restaurant with what I would call traditional American fare, but the one downside is the rather exorbitant prices, which I guess is to be expected in Paradise Valley.  

I initially came into El Chorro for a drink with some friends, and I always like to browse the menu at restaurants whether I am eating or not...then I saw one of their 'classics' and had flashbacks to my mother's amazing homemade beef stroganoff.  Now days in the land of trendy, fusion, hip restaurants such things are not very typical to a menu, so I had to try it and see if it could even compare to my mother's version.  Most stroganoffs at restaurants tend to be on the very creamy side and my mother's is heavier on the au jus from the meat and flavor of the mushrooms, so I asked our amazing bartender if it could be modified (also because I am not a fan of ultra creamy sauces anyway); he obliged and informed me the Chef was in house that evening and he would go consult him.  The bartender came back with outstanding news that the chef would cook it up himself :)  

While my meal was in the 'developmental stage' in the back, I finally made it around to deciding on a cocktail.  The bartender was pleasant and asked about my favorite kind of beverage.  I told him I was a big fan of gin, and he said he had the perfect cocktail for me to try: the French 75.  It was a lovely perfumey, bubbly drink that wasn't too sweet or strong (many gin drinks are heavy on the liquor).  For all you people that think gin tastes like pine needles, you need to try some Nolet's Gin; it is more like an English rose garden.  I wouldn't drink that drink regularly, but it was very delicious, flavorful and perfect for good conversation and sipping.  All of my friends tried it and thought it was amazing and couldn't believe there was gin in it haha!
